etymologies: Middle English: from Old French rolle (noun), roller (verb), from Latin rotulus ‘a roll’, variant of rotula ‘little wheel’, diminutive of rota

definitions: move or cause to move in a particular direction by turning over and over on an axis

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

examples.text: the car rolled down into a ditch

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

examples.text: she rolled the ball across the floor

shortDefinitions: move by turning over and over on axis

definitions: turn or cause to turn over to face a different direction

examples.text: she rolled onto her side
they rolled him over onto his back

shortDefinitions: turn over to face different direction

definitions: turn (one's eyes) upward, typically to show surprise or disapproval

examples.text: Sarah rolled her eyes

shortDefinitions: turn one's eyes upwards

definitions: (of a person or animal) lie down and turn over and over while remaining in the same place

examples.text: the buffalo rolled in the dust

shortDefinitions: lie down and turn over and over while remaining in same place

definitions: (of a moving ship, aircraft, or vehicle) rock or oscillate around an axis parallel to the direction of motion

examples.text: the ship pitched and rolled

shortDefinitions: rock or oscillate around axis parallel to direction of motion

definitions: move along or from side to side unsteadily or uncontrollably

examples.text: they were rolling about with laughter

shortDefinitions: move along or from side to side unsteadily or uncontrollably

definitions: overturn (a vehicle)

examples.text: he rolled his Mercedes in a 100 mph crash

shortDefinitions: overturn

definitions: throw (a die or dice)

examples.text: he put all his chips on the table and rolled the dice

shortDefinitions: throw

definitions: obtain (a particular score) by throwing a die or dice

examples.text: roll a 2, 3, or 12

shortDefinitions: obtain particular score by doing this

definitions: (of a vehicle) move or run on wheels

examples.text: the van was rolling along the highway

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move or run on wheels

definitions: move or push (a wheeled object)

examples.text: Pat rolled the cart back and forth

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move or push

definitions: (of a drop of liquid) flow

examples.text: huge tears rolled down her cheeks

shortDefinitions: flow

definitions: (of time) elapse steadily

examples.text: the years rolled by

shortDefinitions: elapse steadily

definitions: (of waves, smoke, cloud, or fog) move or flow forward with an undulating motion

examples.text: the fog rolled across the fields

shortDefinitions: move or flow forward with undulating motion

definitions: (of land) extend in gentle undulations.
shortDefinitions: extend in gentle undulations

definitions: (of credits for a movie or television program) be displayed as if moving on a roller up the screen

examples.text: the end credits rolled and the title came up

shortDefinitions: be displayed as if moving on roller up screen

definitions: (with reference to a machine, device, or system) operate or begin operating

examples.text: the cameras started to roll
roll the camera

shortDefinitions: (of machine, device, or system) operate or begin operating

definitions: start moving; take action

examples.text: the coast's clear—let's roll

shortDefinitions: start moving

definitions: behave in a particular way

examples.text: that's just how I roll, guys—I'll smile until I physically can't

shortDefinitions: behave in particular way

definitions: turn (something flexible) over and over on itself to form a cylinder, tube, or ball

examples.text: he rolled the handkerchief into a ball

shortDefinitions: turn something flexible over and over on itself to form cylinder or ball

definitions: make (something) by forming material into a cylinder or ball

examples.text: Harry rolled himself a joint

shortDefinitions: make something by forming material into cylinder or ball

definitions: (of a person or animal) curl up tightly

examples.text: the shock made the armadillo roll into a ball

shortDefinitions: curl up tightly

definitions: flatten or spread (something) by using a roller or by passing it between rollers

examples.text: roll out the dough on a floured surface
roll on a decorative paint finish

shortDefinitions: flatten something by passing roller over it or by passing it between rollers

definitions: (of a loud, deep sound such as that of thunder or drums) reverberate

examples.text: the first peals of thunder rolled across the sky

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: reverberate

definitions: pronounce (a consonant, typically an r) with a trill

examples.text: when he wanted to emphasize a point he rolled his rrrs

shortDefinitions: pronounce (consonant) with trill

definitions: utter (a word or words) with a reverberating or vibratory effect

examples.text: he rolled the word around his mouth

shortDefinitions: utter word or words with reverberating or vibratory effect

definitions: (of words) flow effortlessly or mellifluously

examples.text: the names of his colleagues rolled off his lips

shortDefinitions: flow effortlessly or mellifluously

definitions: rob (someone, typically when they are intoxicated or asleep)

examples.text: if you don't get drunk, you don't get rolled

shortDefinitions: rob

definitions: a cylinder formed by winding flexible material around a tube or by turning it over and over on itself without folding

examples.text: a roll of carpet

shortDefinitions: cylinder formed by winding flexible material around tube

definitions: a cylindrical mass of something or a number of items arranged in a cylindrical shape

examples.text: a roll of mints

shortDefinitions: cylindrical mass of something or several items arranged in cylindrical shape

definitions: an item of food that is made by wrapping a flat sheet of pastry, cake, meat, or fish around a sweet or savory filling

examples.text: salmon and rice rolls

shortDefinitions: item of food that is made by wrapping flat sheet of pastry

definitions: money, typically a quantity of banknotes rolled together

examples.text: I should eat out, enjoy the fat roll I'd taken out of my account

shortDefinitions: quantity of banknotes rolled together

definitions: a movement in which someone or something turns or is turned over on itself

examples.text: a roll of the dice
the ponies completed two rolls before getting back on their feet

shortDefinitions: movement in which person or thing turns or is turned over on itself

definitions: a gymnastic exercise in which the body is rolled into a tucked position and turned in a forward or backward circle

examples.text: I used my momentum and tucked into a roll

shortDefinitions: gymnastic exercise in which person tucks their head down and rolls their bodyr

definitions: a swaying or oscillation of a ship, aircraft, or vehicle around an axis parallel to the direction of motion

examples.text: the car corners capably with a minimum of roll

shortDefinitions: swaying or oscillation of ship, aircraft, or vehicle

definitions: a prolonged, deep, reverberating sound, typically made by thunder or a drum

examples.text: thunder exploded, roll after roll

shortDefinitions: prolonged, deep, reverberating sound

definitions: one of the basic patterns (rudiments) of drumming, consisting of a sustained, rapid alternation of single or double strokes of each stick.
shortDefinitions: one of basic patterns rudiments of drumming

definitions: a very small loaf of bread, to be eaten by one person

examples.text: soup with a roll

shortDefinitions: very small loaf of bread

definitions: an official list or register of names

examples.text: the school had no one by his name on its roll

shortDefinitions: official list or register of names

definitions: the total numbers on an official list of names

examples.text: a review of secondary schools to assess the effects of falling rolls

shortDefinitions: total numbers on such list

definitions: a document, typically an official record, in scroll form.
shortDefinitions: document historically kept in scroll form

definitions: undulation of the landscape

examples.text: hidden by the roll of the land was a refinery

shortDefinitions: undulation of landscape

definitions: a roller for flattening something, especially one used to shape metal in a rolling mill.
shortDefinitions: roller for flattening something
